metadata.name: Lands #100
metadata.description:
Lands are a group of artworks creating a minimalist and abstract satellite view. The earth is changing, more and more, day after day, the satellite views are a great proof of that. Stay aware and be careful is important.

I wanted to representing something real, linked with my values, and keep a beautiful composition and colors harmony.  I worked with a new fresh touch for the colors management.

The size, position and frequency of the pieces are generated for each token, along with the color theme. 

Features : 
- piecesCount : the number of circles and rectangles.
- glitchLinesCount :  the number of lines behind the shapes.
- MultipleGlitchDirections : if the directions of the lines behind are just horizontal or vertical, or both (10% of chance to have only one direction) .

 Handmade by code with Javascript, made with fragment.tools
 Quentin Hocdé, Brussels (Belgium), 2023.

metadata.name: Iteration is Usually Recursive (Pt. 1) #97
metadata.description:
This is the companion piece released with 'Iteration is Usually Recursive — Introduction: Finding answers in pre-computational art', the first in a series of essays, some long, some short, on generative art, theory and the practitioners of the medium. 

This piece started a simple experimen recreating George Nees’ Schotter (1968)— a classic piece of generative art history — as vanilla js SVG graphics. From there, I specifically developed it with non-plotter printing in mind, and more specific still, Riso Printing (think a scanner with a digital screen-printer MacGyver’d on). The palettes are taken from hex-estimated Risograph colour gamuts, with three layers being multiplied together to replicate, to some degree, the blending of the semi-transparent Risographic inks. Within this study, there’s a few different things going on, the initial setup is rectangles which cascade down the canvas, inheriting more extreme rotation as they get closer to the bottom (a la Schotter). The second is a subdivision of the shapes with filled circled, outlined circles and squares — since in this study the base shapes are rectangles and not squares, distribution of the ‘dithering’ can be larger than a single ‘pixel’ size — when these multiple layers overlap, the shapes produce a halftone-moire effect, forms and structures appear from the noise as the underlying patterns intersect. 

tx: Who?, Cosimo, Liam Egan, Andreas Rau, Louis

Licensing: CC-BY-NC-ND

metadata.name: Modulacions 2: 'Memory' (audio) #119
metadata.description:
"Modulacions 2: Memory" ies the second piece of the series 'Modulations'. Shorter (at most 12 characters of the Fxhash string) but with memory that is displayed on the screen.

Modulacions (Modulations): modulation with an oscillator (carrier) with an LFO (modulator).

-The LFO is controlled by some of fxhash characters

-Some parameters are randomly assigned to each of the possible characters of the fxhash string (0,1,2....X,Y,Z): carrier frequency, maximum and minimum frequencies of the modulator, waveforms, views etc.

-A number of fxhash characters are selected (4,6,8 or 12), and in order they are played and displayed using the assigned values.

-Each character is encoded in binary-> the LFO frequency is controlled: 1->maximum frequency, 0->minimum frequency.

Features:
·dark: black (true) or white (false).
·carrier_wave: wave shape of carrier oscillator (sine, square, triangle or sawtooth)
·modulator_mult: value of LFO multiplier.
·modulator_sum: value added to LFO amplitude.
·num_fxhash_chars: number of fxhash characters used (4, 6 , 8 or 12)
·carrier_freq_range: frequency range of carrier (low, mid or high).
·frames_per_bit: duration of each bit in frames.(10, 15 or 20)
·one_visual: same visual for all chars (true) or nor (false).

Press 's' to save canvas as png.

-NOTES:
·Headphones recomended. Some extreme sounds (frequency and amplitude) can be generated.
·Preview is randomly generated, the final result can be very different.

-p5js and p5.sound

metadata.name: Hybrid Garden #89
metadata.description:
Step into the Hybrid Garden, where the boundaries between art and technology blur to create a mesmerizing landscape of blooming flowers.

This generative project merges AI-generated floral imagery with the power of code, producing a series of unique and captivating compositions.

Explore the beauty of technology-augmented nature and be amazed by the endless possibilities of the Hybrid Garden


Code implemented in javascript with p5.js library
Original images created with AI
4096 x 4096


Please be patient while image is generated.

metadata.name: Iteration is Usually Recursive (Pt. 1) #120
metadata.description:
This is the companion piece released with 'Iteration is Usually Recursive — Introduction: Finding answers in pre-computational art', the first in a series of essays, some long, some short, on generative art, theory and the practitioners of the medium. 

This piece started a simple experimen recreating George Nees’ Schotter (1968)— a classic piece of generative art history — as vanilla js SVG graphics. From there, I specifically developed it with non-plotter printing in mind, and more specific still, Riso Printing (think a scanner with a digital screen-printer MacGyver’d on). The palettes are taken from hex-estimated Risograph colour gamuts, with three layers being multiplied together to replicate, to some degree, the blending of the semi-transparent Risographic inks. Within this study, there’s a few different things going on, the initial setup is rectangles which cascade down the canvas, inheriting more extreme rotation as they get closer to the bottom (a la Schotter). The second is a subdivision of the shapes with filled circled, outlined circles and squares — since in this study the base shapes are rectangles and not squares, distribution of the ‘dithering’ can be larger than a single ‘pixel’ size — when these multiple layers overlap, the shapes produce a halftone-moire effect, forms and structures appear from the noise as the underlying patterns intersect.

metadata.name: Efflorescence #71
metadata.description:
Efflorescence: the period when flowers start to appear on a plant and the time and process of budding and unfolding of blossoms, It also means the production of a lot of art and developments.
Therefore, this work reminds me of the happy moments when I produce works of art and get immersed in them. This work can be printed in large dimensions, to see the artwork in high quality, open it in live view and add “&res=1 to 10” to the URL.

Made with p5js and love.
